nodes.bodyText:
I don't think I fully understand this, so want to make sure I do.
We're grabbing the entryPoint and main modules, as well as any modules they transitively import. We're also grabbing any entryModule (which I guess would be something like the proving module?), but not the transitive imports of the entryModules? And we're specifically only grabbing entryModules which have bubbles which need parsing.
I guess my questions are:

Why not get transitive imports of entryModules()?
Why not apply the filter for only modules with bubbles across all the modules, not just the entryModules()?

so, Definition.entryModules is a bit of a misnomer insofar as it contains every module that was included in the K files you parsed. that's why we're not doing a transitive closure there. And specifically we are only grabbing those modules which /don't/ contain bubbles. And the only reason we are doing this is because some of them are required to exist in the parser, like some of the ones in kast.k.
Ok, so it's an over-approximation of the modules needed to do parsing.

I recommend a comment explaining the above logic. Lack of comments in such places is a reason why code is hard to maintain.
I don't see any advantage to build a Stream then to convert it to Set. You should create a Set from start. Code will look simpler. If you want the preserve the iterating order then use LinkedHashSet.
Please add comments where you see fit.
